body:
As far as I can see, the difference when deleting one of the mentioned files is that:

[if (allocationExpression.binding != null)](https://github.com/INRIA/spoon/blob/master/src/main/java/spoon/support/compiler/jdt/JDTTreeBuilder.java#L2139)

becomes `true` and, thus:

[references.getTypeReference(b)](https://github.com/INRIA/spoon/blob/master/src/main/java/spoon/support/compiler/jdt/JDTTreeBuilder.java#L2149) is omitted (which itself calls `setSimpleName` [in case of a PolyTypeBinding](https://github.com/INRIA/spoon/blob/master/src/main/java/spoon/support/compiler/jdt/JDTTreeBuilder.java#L1031)).

The bug doesn't come from Spoon but JDT.

I create a test case with your zip file and the source code impacted by the bug is this part:

``` java
return new TOIssue(
        issue.getId(),
        issue.getIdentifier(),
        issue.getTitle(),
        issue.getDescription(),
        issue.getUrl(),
        issue.getAuthor().getRepresentativeName(),

        labels,
        versions,

        Date.from(issue.getCreatedAt().toInstant()),
        closedAt == null ? null : Date.from(issue.getClosedAt().toInstant()),

        issue.getIssueType().toString());
```

In `JDTTreeBuilder`, we build the `CtConstructorCall` and we iterate on all arguments. All types of these arguments are good, except for `closedAt == null ? null : Date.from(issue.getClosedAt().toInstant())`.

See all these types on the capture below:

![capture d ecran 2016-07-27 a 16 12 51](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1913901/17178340/61922a22-5415-11e6-80f4-57ff324f6733.png)

I can create an issue on the JDT bug tracker but I'm not very optimistic... They don't like bug report on noclasspath errors.
what about simply removing the throw exception?

I'm not entirely sure if this really is a JDT related issue. I found that the parameter `closedAt == null ? null : Date.from(issue.getClosedAt().toInstant())` is a `PolyTypeBinding` (as we can see in your screenshot) holding a `ConditionalExpression`. This `PolyTypeBinding` gets processed by `JDTTreeBuilder` in [line 930](https://github.com/INRIA/spoon/blob/f57cd71363273703a8b31364fb206eb50df75f4e/src/main/java/spoon/support/compiler/jdt/JDTTreeBuilder.java#L930) by utilizing a `ReferenceBuilder` to retrieve its type reference (`parameters.add(references.getTypeReference(b));`). `getTypeReference` itself creates a `CtTypeReference` (actually a `CtReferenceImpl`) with simple name [`binding.readableName()`](https://github.com/INRIA/spoon/blob/76b364813dc954edee1eb75c2d712a833731bcc1/src/main/java/spoon/support/compiler/jdt/ReferenceBuilder.java#L682) which, in turn, returns the String `closedAt == null ? null : Date.from(issue.getClosedAt().toInstant())`. The exception is finally thrown by `setSimpleName` since `closedAt == null ? null : Date.from(issue.getClosedAt().toInstant())` contains a "?".

So, I think the issue results from `binding.readableName()` returning a String containing a "?". Although this function is part of JDT, the returned String makes perfectly sense since the readable name of a `ConditionalExpression` actually contains a "?". I'm not sure how to fix the issue yet, but I think it should be fixed by Spoon not by JDT. 

EDIT: Spoon may have to handle a `PolyTypeBinding` holding a `ConditionalExpression` separately.

> what about simply removing the throw exception?

I will try it.

@retuxx JDT shouldn't return a `PolyTypeBinding` but a `BinaryTypeBinding` of a `Boolean` type. The type isn't evaluated by JDT and returns a bad type. `allocationExpression.argumentTypes` should returns all types evaluated by JDT for the constructor call and a `PolyTypeBinding` with `closedAt == null ? null : Date.from(issue.getClosedAt().toInstant())` isn't a type.

@monperrus You want to remove a production check? You? :)
@GerardPaligot Doesn't this imply that the provided source code is not compilable with Eclipse?

@retuxx Not necessarily but there may be strange behavior.

Think too that we don't use the latest version of JDT.
Could Spoon evaluate the type by its own?
Unfortunately, not. Maybe @tdurieux or @monperrus have an idea to know how we can do this without removing the production check?
What about finding the common base type of the `if` and `else` expression and use its name to setup the simple name?

rename.from: A reference can't have a "?" in its name.
rename.to: exception in noclasspath with ternary expressions due to PolyTypeBinding

body: Any progress here? I'm really looking forward to have this work.

We are trying to figure out when JDT uses PolyTypeBinding, in order to create the best patch.
But there is no doc for PolyTypeBinding...

Did you try my snippet?

> Did you try my snippet? 

Not yet. I thought this is more a quick hack than a proper fix.
